title: How are the challenges addressed in the common framework?
segmentation: I can answer the questions.
I will will, with the help of Frank Norris answer the questions, but not now.
I will do that in the session after lunch.
It's about interoperability.
But in order to be able to do that, I need to to sort of try try to tell you how do we actually communicate in this business of resolving the issue with the teddy bears.
Peterson get my presentation up there please.
Does not want.
So, so the common framework is literally the language that these people who need to cooperate in order to get the teddy bears home safely, that the language that they need to speak.

Because if we don't do that, I mean Yahoo demonstrated is very nicely this morning he had a name that even I couldn't pronounce an if we really started to to push this to the extreme, he would be speaking Dutch.
I would speak in Norwegian, and even though we can read our each other's newspapers, maybe we cannot communicate by word of mouth.
So we need something else.
So.
Yahoo is here partly DHL and partly representing the GS One Logistics Forum or the ecom working Group within that forum.
And I'm asking now what does the this forum and the US Department of Transport have in common?
They have in common the fact that they are striving for improved interoperability.
And they are both doing that in parallel.
And they are hardly talking to each other.
That's not a good thing.
Before Venice, these projects were also doing.
Things relating to information exchange.
On a major thing happened then because we decided to try to cooperate.
Because we felt it was a good thing to do.
It was it's much better having one basic common framework for information exchange than each individual organization.
Project having another one.
And we had when we did this we had alternative starting points.
We could start with the standards like UNC fact like UBL.
There are two major international standard organization GS.
One is not there yet.
We didn't know too much about them at the time, sorry.
There were two 2 places to start and we realized when we when we looked around and said that even industries are looking for new ways of interaction.
Where by these ecom group in GS One is 1 example.
So we did not feel very comfortable with starting with that approach, which did not lead to true interoperability.

So we had a project called trade wise that happened to be finishing this April and from this they came at least the conceptual ideas that forms the basis or one of the basis of what we now call the the common framework.
And before I go any further I need to to just respond to jaco's one of your causes statement and say that yes conceptually this may be fine.
The challenge is to get you guys to use it.
You and the others, so we will definitely work with you to try to achieve that.
And one of the reasons why Arcots it's here and one of the reason why I'm standing here is that, at least for the time we have until we sort of disagree too much, we have decided to work together.
Therefore hopefully this will be a common path from now on.
The starting point that we had in freight wise was for transport user transport service provider.
As to commercial roles.
Then we have transportation network Manager dealing with information by the infrastructure and we have the transport regulator which is about.
Everything to do with customs and other things like this.
When we started to have a dialogue with GS One, we realized that there were more commonality's than there were differences and they had exactly the same two roles there, but they called it different.
They called it a logistic services client and logistics services provider.
Other than that, we were OK.
However, they had a scope that was beyond the scope or where we have been in the past because they said, and that's part of this warehouse thing.
Again, that transport cannot be considered independent of trade.
Transport is part of the complete process.
Which letters to say that we cannot either when we are thinking about our E freight or or are common framework thing have this in isolation.
Is this about the process which is partly ordering products?
Partly then fulfilling the contracts and invoicing between trading partners and somewhere in there, there's logistics.
So we have to fit in that total picture.
That was also a scope beyond what we have been doing.
These past projects.

Our concentration had been in the actual simple transport operations, namely doing operational planning, planning the transport of the teddy bears without any form of warehousing in between, then actually making sure that the transport went OK and that the bills were settled afterwards.
Dealing with GS one, though we said that, well, we in order to have a complete framework we have to expand.
We have to really take also the view of those long term planning activities, not just the operational planning activities in order to get the complete totality.
So I'll drop this one because it's just.
What we what we said when we did freight wise was that.
If we count the number of messages out there.
It's quite a big number and the cost of actually achieving entrepreneur interoperability between parties is very high.
So what we then also said that we will try to keep the number of messages to a minimum.
In order to make it simple for people to implement.
And we we then.
In the freight Wise Project, which is a starting point here, we'd say that there is one thing missing.
Non organization, have it.
It's the standard definition of a transport service.
So the transport service description was the first thing we defined.
Secondly, if today you talk about booking processes, you have a number of them.
You have preliminary bookings, you have a firm bookings you have.
Other types of interaction mechanisms prior to get to the final booking and there are different messages covering all those different things.
And if you look at these messages, they are essentially highly redundant, so we said why have many when you can do with one and that one.
We have been calling the transport execution plan.

Which will then be communicated between the transport user or logistic services client and the logistics services provider until they agree that it's ready for execution, and at that time the itinerary for the for the cargo is finished, which is much like me booking my air ticket here.
I have a direct ticket which is the transport execution plan from Oslo to Bremen.
And I have a dictionary which tells me they have to stop over in Copenhagen, so so these conceptual things are exactly what that we use the same thing as we use when we are traveling as individuals.

There is obviously a possibility of reporting status and there is an ability for logistic service providers to take input from those dealing with the transport infrastructure when they are doing long-term and operational planning.
Anne.
Even to the point when if a vessel is approaching.

Antwerp, if you go to an Phillip you need to help sail up the Schelde and somewhere in there there's a lock to be operated that operated that lock may be blocked, so your estimate estimated arrival time from the captain.

Who doesn't know about the problem with the lock is 1 and if you really want to be assure you talked to the lock operator and say, will this ship actually be able to come here at the time then you might get some some added quality to the to the ETA so that what we call the transport operation status.
At one point in time, we also thought that the transport execution plan could be used for communicating to the customs, etc.
But we have gotten beyond that.
Cause in our current work we have introduced what we call the single transport document which will be quote that document which is being.
Intended for.
Reporting all form of reporting about transport from commercial operators to authorities.
And this single transport document will be looking conceptual like this.
There's at some administrative information, some cargo relative information, and vehicle rate information for truck, train, ship, barge plane.
Obviously we will see that the transport execution plan and the other thing has information enough in it to actually be able to produce this type of standard transport document.
Part of one of the reasons why the teddy bears came safely home was that at least the container was sealed.
And that that this deal worked throughout.
However, today there are many providers of container seals and they all talk differently.

So in these projects, integrity and smart CM they have decided or defined what they call the standard or security data message, which then is able to communicate information about a variety of such sales to those who need that type of information, and that may be commercial people.
And it may be authorities like customs.
The top there.
How do we then sort of shape this into a total picture?
And we do that by going back to our rolls again and the consignor consignee and the logistic services client belongs in what we call the transport demand domain.
Logistic service provider is transport supply.
Cooperative Systems, last traffic management, etc.
Is this domain, and then we have the supply chain security and compliance, customs etc.

These are the complainant, the messages that we have been speaking about actually then lives partly between the transport demand and transport supply, and here is where we really will have the challenge.
That Taco was that Jaco was speaking about.
Namely, these are very different from the type of messages out there currently.
Their names, their conceptual thoughts, maybe even are different from what is is traditional thoughts in in transport industry or naturistic industry.
So we will see here how we can then compromise between the conceptual things and the practical experiences into something which becomes operational in the end.

We have information between the traffic traffic management systems etc and transport supply and we have information changed between the transport supply area and transport chain security and compliance.
And from an information point of view, that's all there is.
Part of that part of the framework which will not been speaking about here at all is 1, which is very, very important part of the GS.
One ecom work, a process is.
Which we need to add to this in order to make this picture complete.
So that is part of the thing that will have to come later.
Intelligent Cargo was mentioned even with this paper in the morning.
Anne and.
I think it's very important to say that what they were speaking about was an architecture.
Which is more technical than this scope?
This conceptual thing here so.
As I'll let Paolo talk about that that aspect later.
But there is no conflict between whatever we're talking about in intelligent cargo and these conceptual issues that we've been speaking about so far.
So what do we do as proposed actions after this?
There's a lot of things to be done and I will not deal with that at the moment, since Paolo is also going to talk about that.

Standardization activities is by definition the most important as far as I'm concerned, and that is the cooperation that we have established with GS1 Logistics Forum by far the most important one in the short and long term.
Thank you.
